title: After Taxing Rescue, France Vows to Restore Notre Dame
summary: As officials assess fire damage, France's business elite promises hundreds of millions to restore cathedral. PARIS-More than 1,000 people were celebrating Mass inside Notre Dame Cathedral on Monday evening, listening to a Gospel reading while more than 100 feet above their heads, concealed by the famed vaulted ceilings, a canopy of fire was spreading.

title: T-Mobile-Sprint Deal Runs Into Resistance From DOJ Antitrust Staff
summary: DOJ staff members told wireless rivals deal is unlikely to be approved as structured, according to people familiar with matter. Justice Department antitrust enforcement staff have told T-Mobile US Inc. and Sprint Corp. that their planned merger is unlikely to be approved as currently structured, according to people familiar with the matter, casting doubt on the fate of the $26 billion deal.

title: SEC's Lone Democrat Expected to Step Down in Fall
summary: Departure of Robert Jackson Jr. could lead to rightward shift for commission's regulatory decisions. title: The Quiet Revolt That Saved China
summary: Forty years ago, farmers in Xiaogang village split their commune into family plots. A record harvest followed.. The People's Republic of China turns 70 in October and will celebrate with flag-waving and fireworks. But 2019 marks several other major Chinese anniversaries whose public remembrance the Communist Party will suppress-and another milestone whose observance has been surprisingly muted.

title: Trump's Sanctuary-City Stunt
summary: What sense does it make to send aliens to places where authorities won't help track them down?. Immigration was Donald Trump's signature issue in 2016, yet the situation on the southern border has worsened on his watch. In February, illegal border crossings reached their highest level in a decade and show no signs of slowing. The White House blames Democrats, but that argument only gets you so far.

title: Europe's Alternative to Medicare for All
summary: Swiss and Dutch private insurance provide better coverage than Canada's single-payer system.. Sen. Bernie Sanders described his Medicare for All legislation in a Fox News town hall the other night: "What we are talking about is simply a single-payer insurance program, which means that you will have a card which says Medicare on it, you go to any doctor that you want, you will go to any hospital that you want." He added that "you're not paying any more premiums, you're not paying any more copayments, you're not paying any more deductibles." In another context, he said the plan "would allow all Americans, regardless of their income, to get the health care they need when they need it."

summary: Opposition legislators, legal experts and the business sector immediately criticize the decision. title: Los Angeles Archdiocese Pays $8 Million to Sex-Abuse Victim

title: A Silly Lawsuit Over School Lunches
summary: States go to court to demand nutritional standards they could impose on their own.. Seven Democratic attorneys general are suing the Trump administration to stop the U.S. Department of Agriculture from loosening Obama-era school nutrition regulations. The lawsuit-filed by California, Illinois, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, Vermont and the District of Columbia-claims the USDA relaxed sodium and whole-grain requirements without offering the public a chance to comment "and in contravention of nutritional requirements for school meals established by Congress."

title: 'White' Review: Repeat Offender
summary: A Hollywood-connected libertine takes aim at liberals and then trolls them with some well-worn conservative tropes.. Bret Easton Ellis likes to offend people. His first novel, the best-selling "Less Than Zero" (1985), published when Mr. Ellis was 21 and a junior at Bennington College, romanticized the affluent sex-and-drug-crazed youth culture of 1980s Los Angeles. In "American Psycho" (1991), his third and most infamous work, a young, wealthy and drug-addicted investment banker carries out a series of brutal murders, or at least thinks he does. So shocking were that novel's descriptions of violence that Simon & Schuster yielded to internal protests and dropped the book before publication. (It was published by Vintage instead.)

title: Marquee Buys Martha Stewart, Emeril Lagasee Brands

title: Secrets of Nashville's Success
summary: Everyone's favorite boom town just happens to be located in a business-friendly state.. Today the Drudge Report has been linking to the latest newspaper story on the long-running economic and cultural boom in Nashville, Tennessee. Like many such stories today's dispatch in the Guardian mentions the vibrant music scene, which goes way beyond the country acts that made the city famous, as well as the growth of various industries from health care to technology. Also, as in many such stories, there's no mention of the fact that Nashville happens to be located in a state with no tax on wage income.

title: The Changing Digital World of IPO Listings
summary: For the past five years, Nasdaq has operated the largest liquidity pool in U.S. equities, providing the most efficient marketplace for our companies.. "IPO Bonanza Sparks Battle" (page one, April 6) gives the impression that exchanges focus only on visibility to win a listing. As an exchange, our capabilities to support corporate clients at all stages of their life cycles are what matters. While we are proud to create a milestone moment that is unique and special for our listed companies by celebrating their IPO day, more importantly, we are committed to supporting them every day as public companies. For the past five years, Nasdaq has operated the largest liquidity pool in U.S. equities, providing the most efficient marketplace for our companies, which also benefit from a comprehensive suite of trading, visibility and corporate solutions. Nasdaq also has a thriving index business for our listed companies to gain exposure to passive investors.

title: Time to Get U.S. Soldiers Out of Afghanistan
summary: The U.S. will continue to be a major player in Afghanistan even without thousands of troops on the ground. The sooner Washington recognizes this, the sooner our men and women in uniform can come home after so many years at war.. The death of three U.S. service members near Bagram Airfield is one more grim reminder of a conflict in Afghanistan that has proceeded in almost autopilot fashion ("Americans Are Killed In Afghan Attack," World News, April 9). The American people are justifiably exhausted by this conflict, one that seems to continue with little light at the end of the tunnel. Fortunately, it doesn't have to be this way.

title: Cheats, SATs and What Colleges Should Be
summary: Mr. McGurn, respectfully, do we really want an admissions system where test scores are all that matter?. Regarding William McGurn's "Cheating on the SATs" Main Street, April 9): Mr. McGurn, respectfully, do we really want an admissions system where test scores are all that matter? When you say that a formula other than a straight "merit-based entrance exam" would mean admitting "less-qualified students at the expense of more-qualified students," you're essentially stating that a student who, for example, played three sports in high school, was first chair cello for four years, is active in an organization dedicated to bringing awareness to mental illness and depression, all while maintaining a 4.0 GPA, but gets a 1500 versus another student who does none of those things but gets a 1600, is less-qualified than the other student to be admitted to a selective school?

title: Loud 'Sopranos' Shirts: Better Left on Reruns
summary: As the iconic HBO show celebrates its 20th anniversary, we look at one of its most controversial style legacies: the garish, printed button-up shirt. TRUE FANS bond over Tony Soprano's Tabasco shirt. In season five of the HBO drama, "The Sopranos," which made its debut 20 years ago, the pugnacious mafia patriarch played by the late James Gandolfini wore an eyesore of a polo shirt, its print depicting teensy hot sauce bottles and dancing chile peppers. title: Photos: A New Glimpse of '80s New York in Paige Powell's Book Set
summary: A new book set, full of photographs from Paige Powell's archives and essays by her friends, debuts on April 17. Paige Powell's first job was teaching chimpanzees sign language at what is now the Oregon Zoo. In 1980, she moved from Portland to New York City with more artistic aspirations in mind, determined to work for either Andy Warhol or Woody Allen. She landed offers from not just one but both men, and took an advertising position at Warhol's Interview after knocking on the bulletproof glass doors of the magazine's office. Her in-person cold call involved regaling the staff with anecdotes from her time at the zoo, including her success at selling Zoo Doo-elephant dung repurposed as fertilizer-"by the truckload."

Some of the earliest investors in IEX Group Inc. recently sold their stakes in the upstart stock exchange, including activist hedge funds Third Point LLC and Pershing Square Capital Management LP, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Investors Suffer a Smoking Relapse
summary: Tobacco stocks have outperformed the S&P 500 since the start of the year, but the old dangers remain. Much like die-hard smokers, investors are finding it hard to stay away from cigarettes. The lure of tobacco stocks is an income fix, but none of the big risks have really gone away.

title: Futures Guru Targets Libor Replacement
summary: Richard Sandor, known for creating futures markets in the 1970s, has a new Libor alternative that is gaining traction. A leading figure behind the creation of futures markets in the 1970s is joining the race to replace the benchmark interest-rate underpinning trillions of dollars worth of financial contracts world-wide.

title: Building a Case For Chinese Property
summary: Two recent policy changes might be enough to head off a widely expected downturn. In late 2018, housing essentially held up China's economy as export growth slowed and consumers retrenched. While there is widespread concern that a property downturn is around the corner, this may yet be proven wrong.

title: Families Use Apps to Track Relatives With Dementia
summary: Technology can keep tabs on people with dementia, but apps crash, batteries die and systems fail. Kim Rice tracks her husband's every move, including his arrival home each night from adult day care.

title: Burning Man's Future in Question Amid Fight With Government Agency
summary: Bureau of Land Management's proposal for physical barriers and dumpsters have 'Burners' aflame. GERLACH, Nev.-One of the main principles of Burning Man is "radical inclusion," but organizers of the annual festival in the desert are taking radical exception to new government proposals they say would kill its countercultural spirit.

title: Finance's Top Earners Don't Work at a Bank
summary: REITs had some of the highest median worker pay among financial, real-estate and insurance firms, annual company disclosures show. The best place to make money in the world of finance and investment may not be at a bank but in real estate.

title: Government to Measure Who Gets What Share of the Economic Pie
summary: Analysts take on question of how wealth is distributed among rich, poor and middle amid concern about inequality. U.S. workers produced $20.5 trillion in goods and services last year, but that measure of output said nothing about how the economy's spoils were divvied up, who benefited most from what the economy delivered and who got the least.

title: IBM Seeks Revenue Rebound in Cloud
summary: Tuesday's results come as the computing behemoth struggles through successive quarters of revenue declines. International Business Machines Corp. is expected to report first-quarter earnings after the market closes Tuesday. The results come as the computing behemoth struggles through successive quarters of revenue declines. Here's what to expect:

title: What Retail Recovery? Malls Under Pressure as Stores Close
summary: Delayed openings, recent drop in retail sales signal malls aren't 'out of the woods yet'. Strong retail numbers last year from department stores Macy's Inc. and Nordstrom Inc. raised hopes that the beleaguered mall industry would finally rebound.

title: When Central Banks Try to Fix What They Break
summary: The European Central Bank would only take interest rates more negative with a mechanism to soften the blow on banks. Fears of a global economic slowdown have led the European Central Bank to once again ponder the idea of taking interest rates into deeply negative territory and then come up with ways so to cushion any ill effects. That last bit in itself should be a red flag.

title: Google Quietly Disbanded Another AI Review Board
summary: Panel members in U.K. chafed at lack of information access, authority and independence from Google. LONDON-Google is disbanding a panel here to review its artificial-intelligence work in health care, people familiar with the matter say, as disagreements about its effectiveness dogged one of the tech industry's highest-profile efforts to govern itself.

title: Shanghai Auto Show in Pictures
summary: Compact electric SUVs are everywhere at Auto Shanghai 2019, as auto makers aim for the hottest spot in China's chilly car market. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Netanyahu Begins Building Fragile Coalition in Israel
summary: Prime minister gets formal support from small political parties but still needs to mend disagreements in his coalition. TEL AVIV-Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu began trying to form a government Monday that would continue supporting him if he is charged with corruption and won't splinter over the disagreements that fractured his last coalition.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Beto O'Rourke Underpaid Two Years of Taxes
summary: Democratic candidate's returns reveal an error in medical expense deductions in 2013, 2014. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke and his wife, Amy, appear to have underpaid their 2013 and 2014 taxes by more than $4,000 combined because of an error in the way they reported their medical expenses, according to tax returns the couple released Monday evening.

title: Bernie Sanders Releases Tax Returns
summary: Vermont senator, making his second White House bid, paid total federal taxes of $145,840 on $561,293 in adjusted gross income for 2018. WASHINGTON-Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders released a decade's worth of his tax returns on Monday, showing an annual income that exceeded $1 million in 2016 and 2017 following his first presidential campaign.

title: Tony Nominations Could Give Broadway Shows a Second Act
summary: Some productions that have had less-than-stellar sales might get a box-office boost, theater professionals say. With the announcement of the Tony Award nominations a couple of weeks away, some buzzworthy Broadway shows that have had less-than-stellar sales could be in line for a boost at the box office, theater professionals say.

title: Fed Official Open to Adopting an Inflation Target Range
summary: Boston Fed's Eric Rosengren backs allowing inflation over 2% in good economic times. The leader of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston said he favors the central bank moving from using interest-rate policy to achieve 2% inflation to a regime that targets a range of price pressures, in remarks that also offer a positive view of the U.S. economy.
